article.description: Syracuse won at the buzzer against the Hoyas on Saturday.
article.headline: McNamara hits at buzzer for Orangemen
article.linkText: Orange crush: Syracuse beats Hoyas at buzzer
article.story: WASHINGTON (AP) -- Gerry McNamara got the ball without a second to spare, then stepped back and tossed in the game-winner at the buzzer. McNamara, who had struggled with his outside shot most of the game, somehow found nothing but net to create another classic Big East moment between longtime rivals. The desperation heave gave Syracuse a 57-54 victory over Georgetown on Saturday. "I just let it fly," said McNamara, who made his last three 3-pointers after missing six in a row. "It was probably the best shot I'd taken all day." McNamara got the pass from Hakim Warrick, who had nearly lost control of the ball after hurriedly working the length of the court in traffic after Georgetown tied the game with 8.3 seconds left. McNamara had two defenders around him when he shot. "I don't know how that shot could possibly go in," Syracuse coach Jim Boeheim said. "That was an incredible shot. I was getting ready for overtime." Warrick had 19 points and five of Syracuse's 12 blocks, and McNamara finished with 13 points for the Orangemen (17-6, 7-5), who survived a season-high 25 turnovers and 50 percent shooting from the free throw line. "That shows some heart," Warrick said of the scrappy nature of the win. "And that's something we haven't had the last couple of games." Syracuse freshman Louie McCroskey added 10 points, his second career-high in as many games. Gerald Riley and Ashanti Cook each scored 13 points for Georgetown (13-10, 4-8), which lost its fourth straight. Cook also had six steals. The Hoyas played some of their best defense of the season -- an inspired effort coming off a bad loss at St. John's -- but they shot just 28 percent from the field. "We did a great job of recovering form a very poor showing," said Georgetown coach Craig Esherick, whose team might need a strong finish just to qualify for the Big East tournament. "Clearly the effort was there." Syracuse forward Josh Pace's short hook tied the game at 52 with 1:40 to play. Riley missed a 12-footer for Georgetown, and Warrick gave the Orangemen the lead with two free throws with 51 seconds to play. Courtland Freeman then tied the game at 54 when he tipped in Matt Causey's miss with 8.3 seconds remaining. Syracuse played so poorly in the first half, it was somewhat incredible that the defending national NCAA champions only trailed 25-22. The Orangemen committed seven turnovers in the first five minutes and had 13 at halftime, already more than their season average of 12.3. Warrick committed his third foul on a needless reach-in after the rebound with 5.9 seconds left. Syracuse went 5:46 without scoring a point, but Georgetown managed just an 8-0 run during the drought to take a tenuous 30-22 lead with 17 minutes remaining. McNamara helped steady the Orangemen when he finally found his shooting touch. He hit a pair of 3-pointers -- and converted one into a four-point play -- to cut the lead to one with 4:20 remaining. "With him, he'll keep taking shots. And just when you think he's off, he'll hit two or three at a critical point in the game," Esherick said.
